contentrichtext.text: {{one source|date=August 2012}} '''Muse Software''' was a [[Baltimore]]-based [[software publisher|software]] and [[video game publisher|computer game publisher]] and [[video game developer|developer]] for the first generation of [[home computer]]s. They first published for the [[Apple II]] under the name Micro Users Software Exchange, and later expanded to the [[Commodore 64]], [[Atari]], and the [[IBM PC]]. ==History== MUSE was founded in 1978 by [[Ed Zaron]]. [[Silas Warner]] was MUSE Software's first employee. Initially publishing games, the team also sold non-game software such as ''[[Super-Text]]'' (written by Zaron), a [[word processor]], and ''[[Appilot]]'' (written by Warner), a course-writing language. Their original market was for the Apple II and II+, with their first programs sold on [[compact audio cassette#Data recording|cassette]], and later on [[floppy disk]]. They expanded their software offerings for other computers, such as the [[Commodore 64]] and the [[Atari 800]]. The company also ran a retail store on the corner of Charles and Mulberry Streets in Baltimore called "Muse Software and Computer Center" which closed to the public in 1982.<ref name="baltimoresun3">[http://proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com.proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/docview/909366949 University of Baltimore]</ref> At its peak, Muse was making more than $2 million per year in sales.<ref name="baltimoresun3"/> According to Zaron, Muse's sales grew "extremely slow" because of a slump in the home computer software market.<ref name="Baltimore Sun">[http://proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com.proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/docview/533500591 University of Baltimore]</ref> The company, which had about 40 employees at its peak in 1983, had shrunk down to just six prior to filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection in 1985. Warner, who was leaving Muse to join [[Microprose]], said the company had difficulty setting up a sales program because of the long-term illness of a key sales employee. The company closed down in [[1987 in video gaming|1987]]. Hence ''[[Wolfenstein 3D]]'' (the father of [[first-person shooter]] games) was born, trading upon the well-respected name among older gaming enthusiasts.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://retrowaretv.com/castle-wolfenstein-the-original/ | title=Castle Wolfenstein (The Original) | date=July 12, 2012 | accessdate=August 29, 2012}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== {{inline|date=August 2012}} * [http://proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com.proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/docview/533500591 Muse Software firm files for liquidation of assets] * [http://proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com.proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/docview/909366949 Last hurrah for famed computer firm: Auction of Muse assets raises $40,000] * [http://proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com.proxy-ub.researchport.umd.edu/docview/538110059 Muse firm decides to focus energies on programming] ==External links== * [http://www.mobygames.com/company/muse-software/ MobyGames entry on Muse Software] * [http://www.homeoftheunderdogs.net/company.php?name=Muse%20Software The Underdogs entry on Muse Software] {{Muse Software}} [[Category:Companies based in Frederick County, Maryland]] [[Category:Companies established in 1978]] [[Category:Companies disestablished in 1987]] [[Category:Defunct video game companies]] [[Category:Video game companies of the United States]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Video game publishers]]
